questions.q: Do you offer free quotes?
questions.a: Yes, we provide absolutely free, no-obligation security assessments and quotes for all new installations and major upgrades in Cape Town.

questions.q: What areas do you service?
questions.a: We service the entire Cape Town metropolitan area and surrounds, including the Northern Suburbs (Durbanville, Bellville), Southern Suburbs (Claremont, Constantia), Atlantic Seaboard, and the Winelands (Stellenbosch, Paarl).

questions.q: Are you PSIRA registered?
questions.a: Yes, Global Security Solutions and our installation partners adhere to strict PSIRA (Private Security Industry Regulatory Authority) regulations to ensure your safety and legality.

questions.q: Do you offer warranties on installations?
questions.a: Absolutely. All our new installations come with a standard 1-year workmanship warranty, and all hardware carries its respective manufacturer warranty (typically 1-3 years).

questions.q: Can you take over my existing alarm system?
questions.a: Yes, we specialize in 'system takeovers'. We can often repair, upgrade, or link your existing older system to modern monitoring services without a full replacement.

questions.q: Do you offer financing?
questions.a: We generally require a deposit for hardware with the balance due on completion. For large commercial projects, we can discuss phased implementation plans.

questions.q: How long does a typical installation take?
questions.a: A standard home alarm or CCTV installation usually takes 1-2 days. Larger commercial or electric fencing projects may take 3-5 days depending on complexity.

questions.q: Are your technicians vetted?
questions.a: Yes, safety is our priority. All our technicians undergo background checks and are trained to work neatly and respectfully in your home or business.

questions.q: Do you provide 24/7 technical support?
questions.a: We offer emergency technical support for critical failures. For non-critical issues, we have a dedicated support line available during business hours.

questions.q: How do I pay?
questions.a: We accept EFT (Electronic Funds Transfer). Banking details are provided on your invoice. We do not generally accept cash for safety reasons.

questions.q: What is the difference between wired and wireless alarms?
questions.a: Wired systems use physical cables connecting sensors to the panel, making them battery-free (sensor-side) and very reliable but harder to install in finished homes. Wireless systems are quick to install and neat but require battery changes in sensors every 2-3 years.

questions.q: Can I control my alarm from my phone?
questions.a: Yes. We install smart communication modules (like HYYP, Olarm, or AJAX apps) that allow you to arm, disarm, and view system status from your smartphone anywhere in the world.

questions.q: What happens to the alarm during load shedding?
questions.a: Your alarm panel has a backup battery. We ensure this battery is healthy to last 4-8 hours. For higher stages of load shedding, we recommend upgrading to a Lithium-Iron battery or an external power pack.

questions.q: Do you install pet-friendly sensors?
questions.a: Yes, we use 'Pet Immune' PIR sensors that are designed to ignore pets up to a certain weight (usually 15-20kg) while still verifying human movement.

questions.q: Why is my alarm keypad beeping?
questions.a: Beeping usually indicates a trouble condition, such as a low battery, a communication failure, or a mains power loss. Check your keypad display for a trouble light or code.

questions.q: Can you link my alarm to a reaction company?
questions.a: Yes, our systems are compatible with all major armed response companies in Cape Town (e.g., ADT, armed response) via radio or GSM linkage.

questions.q: What is a 'partition' in an alarm system?
questions.a: A partition allows you to arm specific areas separately. For example, you can arm the 'Flatlet' or 'Garage' while leaving the 'Main House' disarmed.

questions.q: How often should I test my alarm?
questions.a: We recommend testing your alarm monthly. Call your control room to put your system on 'test', then trigger a few zones to ensure signals are being received.

questions.q: Do you install outdoor beams?
questions.a: Yes, outdoor beams are the best form of early warning. We install Paradox and Optex beams that detect intruders before they damage your windows or doors.

questions.q: What brands of alarms do you use?
questions.a: We primarily install and support Paradox, IDS, AJAX, and DSC systems due to their reliability and availability of spares.

questions.q: What is the difference between IP and Analog CCTV?
questions.a: Analog (HD-TVI) sends video over coax cable; it is cost-effective and good for upgrades. IP cameras send digital data over network cables, offering higher resolution (4K+), better analytics, and easier scalability.

questions.q: How much recording time will I get?
questions.a: This depends on the hard drive size and number of cameras. Typically, we aim for 2-4 weeks of recording. Motion-triggered recording extends this duration significantly.

questions.q: Can I view my cameras on my phone?
questions.a: Yes, all our Hikvision and Dahua systems come with a free mobile app (Hik-Connect / DMSS) for remote live viewing and playback.

questions.q: Does CCTV work at night?
questions.a: Yes. Modern cameras use IR (Infrared) for black-and-white night vision or ColorVu technology for full-color night vision, even in near-total darkness.

questions.q: Will the cameras work during power cuts?
questions.a: Only if connected to a UPS or inverter. We strongly recommend installing a dedicated mini-UPS for your DVR/NVR and cameras to keep them running during load shedding.

questions.q: Does CCTV record sound?
questions.a: Many modern IP and some HD-TVI cameras have built-in microphones. Please specify if audio recording is a requirement for your site.

questions.q: What is 'motion detection'?
questions.a: The system only records when pixel changes (movement) are detected. Advanced AI cameras can specifically filter for humans and vehicles to ignore rustling trees.

questions.q: Can CCTV identify number plates?
questions.a: Standard cameras can see plates but might struggle with moving cars or headlight glare. For reliable reading, we recommend dedicated ANPR (License Plate Recognition) cameras.

questions.q: Is it legal to have cameras overlooking the street?
questions.a: You may monitor the immediate perimeter of your property for security, but you must respect the privacy of neighbors. Street monitoring is generally acceptable if focused on your entrance.

questions.q: What is the warranty on cameras?
questions.a: Hikvision and Dahua cameras typically come with a 3-year manufacturer warranty.

questions.q: Face recognition vs Fingerprint - which is better?
questions.a: Facial recognition is faster and touchless (hygienic), making it ideal for high-traffic or sterile areas. Fingerprint is reliable and cost-effective but requires physical contact.

questions.q: Can I use my phone to open doors?
questions.a: Yes, utilizing Bluetooth (BLE) or NFC readers allows authorized users to tap their phone or use an app to unlock doors.

questions.q: What happens if the power goes out?
questions.a: All access control systems must have battery backup. Maglocks are 'fail-safe' (unlock on power loss) for fire safety, while strikes can be 'fail-secure' (stay locked).

questions.q: Can I restrict staff access hours?
questions.a: Yes, our software allows Time Zones. You can restrict staff entry to 08:00-17:00 and deny access on weekends.

questions.q: Do you install maglocks for glass doors?
questions.a: Yes, we have specialized brackets for frameless glass doors, inward opening doors, and fire escape doors.

questions.q: What is a 'Tag' system?
questions.a: A tag (or RFID card) system uses a small keyfob. It's affordable and easy to manage—lost tags can be instantly deleted from the system.

questions.q: Can access control track time and attendance?
questions.a: Yes, specifically biometric readers (ZKTeco, etc.). They can export logs compatible with payroll software like Payroll or Excel.

questions.q: How many users can the system handle?
questions.a: Even basic systems handle 1,000+ users. Enterprise systems can handle tens of thousands.

questions.q: Do I need a PC to run the system?
questions.a: Standalone readers don't need a PC. Networked systems for large offices usually require a server or PC for strict management.

questions.q: Can I open the door for a delivery remotely?
questions.a: Yes, if connected to an IP intercom or smart controller, you can release the lock via a mobile app.

questions.q: Can I answer my intercom when I am not home?
questions.a: Yes! IP Intercoms (like Hikvision IP) route the call to your smartphone app if no one answers the indoor monitor.

questions.q: Video vs Audio intercom?
questions.a: Video is far superior for security, allowing you to visually verify the visitor and spot if they are alone or acting aggressively.

questions.q: Does the intercom need a new cable?
questions.a: Ideally, yes (Cat6 data cable). However, we also have Wi-Fi intercoms and 2-wire retro-fit kits that can use existing old cabling in some cases.

questions.q: Can I open the gate from the intercom?
questions.a: Yes, all our intercoms have a 'Gate Release' button wired directly to your gate motor.

questions.q: What is a GSM intercom?
questions.a: A GSM intercom uses a SIM card. It calls your mobile phone like a regular phone call. It's great for complexes or gates far from the house (no cabling needed).

questions.q: Can I have multiple screens in the house?
questions.a: Yes, you can have a main monitor in the kitchen and sub-monitors in the bedroom or study.

questions.q: Is the outdoor station waterproof?
questions.a: Yes, they are IP65 rated against rain and dust. However, we always recommend a rain shield for longevity.

questions.q: Can the intercom record visitors?
questions.a: Many IP video intercoms can take a snapshot or leave a video message if you miss a call.

questions.q: Do you repair old Commax intercoms?
questions.a: We do repair them, but if the unit is very old (15+ years), parts may be discontinued, and a replacement might be more cost-effective.

questions.q: Does it work with a keypad?
questions.a: We can install an intercom with a built-in keypad so you can give access codes to trusted visitors or staff.

questions.q: is electric fencing dangerous to pets?
questions.a: It gives a painful shock but is non-lethal. Most pets learn very quickly to stay away after one accidental touch.

questions.q: Do I need a COC (Certificate of Compliance)?
questions.a: Yes, by law, any new electric fence installation or major alteration requires a COC to ensure it meets safety standards.

questions.q: How much electricity does it use?
questions.a: Very little. An energizer typically consumes about as much power as a 40W light bulb.

questions.q: Will it work during load shedding?
questions.a: Yes, all energizers have a built-in battery backup that usually lasts 6-12 hours.

questions.q: Can plants trigger false alarms?
questions.a: Yes. Vegetation touching the wires causes arcing and voltage drops. You must keep the fence line clear of creepers and branches.

questions.q: What happens if someone cuts the wires?
questions.a: The fence loop is monitored. Cutting a wire breaks the circuit, triggering the siren and notifying your armed response (if linked).

questions.q: Can I have wall-top and free-standing fencing?
questions.a: Yes. Wall-top is common for residential. Free-standing (piggyback) is used for farms or high-security commercial perimeters.

questions.q: How high should the fence be?
questions.a: Standard wall-top brackets range from 5-line (500mm) to 8-line (800mm). The higher, the harder to climb over.

questions.q: What maintenance does it need?
questions.a: Keep vegetation trimmed. Check tensioners every 6 months to ensure wires haven't sagged. Test the battery annually.

questions.q: Is it noisy?
questions.a: A well-maintained fence is silent. A clicking/snapping sound usually means arcing (leaking voltage), which needs repair.

questions.q: What are 'beams'?
questions.a: Beams are outdoor sensors that create an invisible tripwire. If broken by a person, they trigger the alarm before the intruder reaches the house.

questions.q: Do trees block beams?
questions.a: Yes. Point-to-point beams need a clear line of sight. PIR beams need a clear field of view. Garden maintenance is essential for reliable beams.

questions.q: Are wireless beams reliable?
questions.a: Modern wireless beams (like Paradox or Ajax) are very reliable. They save huge labor costs on trenching cables in established gardens.

questions.q: What is the range of outdoor beams?
questions.a: Point-to-point beams can cover 10m to 200m+. Specialized PIRs usually cover a 12m x 90-degree fan area.

questions.q: Do birds trigger beams?
questions.a: Dual-optic beams require *both* top and bottom sensors to be broken instantly. A bird usually only breaks one, preventing false alarms.

questions.q: Can I arm beams while I am sleeping?
questions.a: Yes! This is their main purpose. You 'Sleep Arm' the perimeter while moving freely inside the house.

questions.q: What are Strip Beams?
questions.a: Strip beams are thin vertical sensors placed in window reveals. They detect if a hand or body passes through the window opening.

questions.q: Do beams work in the rain?
questions.a: Yes, quality beams are weather-sealed. However, extremely heavy storms might occasionally lower the signal strength.

questions.q: How high are beams installed?
questions.a: Usually at waist or knee height (800mm) to avoid cats (too low) and being stepped over (too high).

questions.q: Can I link beams to floodlights?
questions.a: Yes, we can wire them to turn on security lights when motion is detected, acting as a double deterrent.

questions.q: Why is my gate opening slowly?
questions.a: It could be a low battery, tight rollers, or a worn motor. Generally, the motor slows down to preserve battery when power is low.

questions.q: How do I stop gate motor theft?
questions.a: We install 'anti-theft cages'—heavy steel brackets that lock over the motor, making it extremely difficult to remove quickly.

questions.q: Can you make my gate open faster?
questions.a: We can upgrade you to a high-speed motor (like the Centurion D5 Evo SMART or D10 Turbo) which opens significantly faster for security.

questions.q: Does the motor work during load shedding?
questions.a: Yes, if the batteries are healthy. High-cycle sites may need additional battery packs to survive frequent stage 6 outages.

questions.q: My remote range is poor, why?
questions.a: It could be a flat remote battery, interference from other devices, or a faulty receiver. We can install an external antenna to boost range.

questions.q: What safety features do gates have?
questions.a: We install safety beams (IR beams) that prevent the gate from closing if a car or child is in the way.

questions.q: Can I open my garage with the same remote?
questions.a: Yes, usually. We can install a receiver on your garage motor that accepts your gate remote signals.

questions.q: Why is the gate sticking?
questions.a: Dirt on the rail, worn wheels, or a bent track are common causes. Regular cleaning of the track is recommended.

questions.q: Can I use my phone to open the gate?
questions.a: Yes, with a GSM module or smart Wi-Fi switch, you can trigger the gate from an app.

questions.q: What is 'Condominium Mode'?
questions.a: A setting where using a remote can only open the gate, not close it (it auto-closes). This prevents one resident from accidentally closing the gate on another.

questions.q: Does the tracker drain my car battery?
questions.a: Modern units draw negligible power. However, if a car sits for weeks, any device will eventually contribute to drain.

questions.q: Can I see where my driver is right now?
questions.a: Yes, fleet systems offer real-time web or app-based maps showing live location and speed.

questions.q: What is 'Slam Lock'?
questions.a: A mechanical lock for courier/delivery vans that automatically locks the door the moment it is slammed shut, preventing opportunist theft.

questions.q: Can you stop the car remotely?
questions.a: Some advanced units allow remote immobilization, safely cutting the engine (usually preventing restart rather than cutting power while moving) for recovery.

questions.q: Do you install dashcams?
questions.a: Yes, we install front and rear dashcams, hardwired so you don't have loose cables hanging.

questions.q: What happens if they disconnect the battery?
questions.a: Tracking units have internal backup batteries that keep them pinging for hours after vehicle power is cut.

questions.q: Is there a monthly fee?
questions.a: Yes, simpler trackers have low fees purely for data. Monitoring and recovery services (like Tracker or Matrix) have higher monthly subscriptions.

questions.q: Can I get a report of trips for tax?
questions.a: Yes, our GPS logbooks generate SARS-compliant trip reports (Business vs Private).

questions.q: How long does installation take?
questions.a: Vehicle tracker installation is quick, usually 1 to 2 hours per vehicle.

questions.q: Can you do installations at my office?
questions.a: Yes, our vehicle technicians are mobile and can fit units at your premises to minimize downtime.

questions.q: What can I automate?
questions.a: Lights, geysers, pool pumps, gate access, garage doors, blinds, and alarm arming/disarming.

questions.q: Does it require new wiring?
questions.a: Not necessarily. We use smart Wi-Fi relays (like Shelly or Sonoff) that fit behind existing light switches and plugs.

questions.q: Does it allow voice control?
questions.a: Yes, most of our systems integrate with Google Home, Amazon Alexa, and Apple HomeKit.

questions.q: Can I set schedules?
questions.a: Yes. You can schedule outside lights to turn on at sunset or your geyser to turn off during peak tariff hours.

questions.q: Is it secure?
questions.a: We use encrypted smart devices and secure Wi-Fi practices. Like any network, a strong password is key.

questions.q: What happens if the internet goes down?
questions.a: Local control (physical switches) still works. Schedules saved on the device may work, but remote app control will be offline.

questions.q: Can I link it to my alarm?
questions.a: Yes! Trigger all house lights to flash red when the alarm goes off—a fantastic visual deterrent.

questions.q: Is it expensive?
questions.a: Modular smart home tech is very affordable. You can start with just one room or the geyser and expand later.

questions.q: Will it work with iPhone and Android?
questions.a: Yes, the apps we use (e.g., eWeLink, Smart Life, Shelly) are available on both iOS and Android.

questions.q: Can automation save electricity?
questions.a: Absolutely. Smart geyser timers and turning off unused appliances automatically can significantly reduce your bill.

questions.q: What is 'Integration'?
questions.a: Making different systems talk to each other. E.g., The electric fence triggering a specific CCTV camera to zoom in.

questions.q: Is integrated security better?
questions.a: Yes, it reduces reaction time and simplifies management (one app instead of four).

questions.q: Can different brands work together?
questions.a: Often, yes, using standard protocols or dry-contact outputs. Hikvision, Paradox, and Control4 often play well together.

questions.q: Do I need a server?
questions.a: For complex integration (VMS software), a server might be needed. For simple linking (Alarm -> Light), basic relays suffice.

questions.q: Can my alarm trigger my beams?
questions.a: Usually it's the other way around: beams trigger the alarm. But we can set up custom logic rules.

questions.q: Is it complicated to use?
questions.a: The setup is complex (for us), but the user experience is designed to be simple (one button press for you).

questions.q: Can you integrate older systems?
questions.a: Sometimes. If the old system has physical input/output terminals, we can usually make it talk to newer smart devices.

questions.q: What about fire detection?
questions.a: Yes, smoke detectors can be integrated into the alarm to open all access control doors automatically for evacuation.

questions.q: Does integration increase maintenance?
questions.a: Slightly, as there are more software links to check, but it generally increases system value and safety.

questions.q: Can I monitor multiple sites?
questions.a: Yes, integrated CMS (Central Management Software) allows viewing multiple branches or homes from one dashboard.

questions.q: Do you repair systems you didn't install?
questions.a: Yes, we are happy to take over, repair, and maintain third-party installations.

questions.q: Is it worth repairing a 10-year-old alarm?
questions.a: Often, the wiring and sensors are fine, but the panel is obsolete. We recommend a board and keypad upgrade utilizing existing wiring.

questions.q: How fast can you come out?
questions.a: For emergencies (siren not stopping, gate stuck), we try to assist same-day. Standard repairs are booked within 24-48 hours.

questions.q: Do you have spares for old remotes?
questions.a: We stock universal remotes and receivers that can replace almost any discontinued remote frequency.

questions.q: Why does my electric fence keep false alarming?
questions.a: Usually arcing due to broken bobbins, vegetation, or a dying battery. We can diagnose this with a 'scope' test.

questions.q: Can you add new sensors to my old wire alarm?
questions.a: Yes, we can add a wireless receiver to your old panel to allow for new wireless sensors.

questions.q: What is the call-out fee?
questions.a: We have a standard call-out fee which covers the first hour of labor/diagnosis. Parts are charged separately.

questions.q: Do you fix corroded circuit boards?
questions.a: No, reliable security requires non-corroded electronics. We replace damaged boards to ensure reliability.

questions.q: Can you upgrade lead-acid to lithium?
questions.a: Yes! This is our most popular upgrade. Lithium (LiFePO4) lasts 5x longer and handles load shedding better.

questions.q: Do repairs come with a warranty?
questions.a: Yes, new parts come with their warranty, and we guarantee our repair labor for 6 months.

questions.q: Why do I need a maintenance contract?
questions.a: Security systems account for safety. Neglect leads to failure when you need it most. Contracts ensure proactive care.

questions.q: What is included in a service?
questions.a: Cleaning cameras/sensors, testing battery load, tensioning fences, verifying siren output, and testing signal transmission.

questions.q: How often do you visit?
questions.a: Typically monthly for commercial/estates, and quarterly or bi-annually for residential.

questions.q: Does the contract cover parts?
questions.a: We have different tiers. 'Comprehensive' covers labor and parts (wear and tear). 'Standard' covers labor only.

questions.q: Are contracts mandatory?
questions.a: No, but they are highly recommended for electric fences (compliance) and critical commercial CCTV.

questions.q: Do contract clients get priority?
questions.a: Yes, SLA clients get guaranteed response times (e.g., 4-hour turnaround) for critical failures.

questions.q: Can I cancel the contract?
questions.a: Yes, standard contracts usually have a 30-day notice period.

questions.q: Do you provide a report?
questions.a: Yes, after every site visit, you receive a health checklist via email noting any issues found.

questions.q: Is it cheaper than ad-hoc repairs?
questions.a: Over time, yes. Preventing a blown power supply or rusted fence is cheaper than replacing it.

questions.q: Which systems need the most maintenance?
questions.a: Electric fencing (tension/vegetation) and outdoor cameras (spiders/dust) require the most frequent care.

questions.q: How do I secure my home while sleeping?
questions.a: Sleep-arming. Use outdoor beams and door magnets to secure the perimeter, allowing you to move freely inside.

questions.q: What is the first layer of home defense?
questions.a: The boundary. A working gate motor, intercom, and electric fence or perimeter beams are your first line of defense.

questions.q: Are wireless alarms good for homes?
questions.a: Excellent. They require no drilling into walls for cables and can be taken with you if you move.

questions.q: Do you install panic buttons?
questions.a: Yes, fixed panic buttons (bedside) and mobile remote panics are essential for personal safety.

questions.q: Can I see my nanny on camera?
questions.a: Yes, indoor nanny cams are common. Legally, you should inform staff that cameras are present.

questions.q: How do I protect my sliding door?
questions.a: We use vibration sensors or heavy-duty magnetic contacts. A 'slam-lock' gate is also a good physical barrier.

questions.q: What if I have large dogs?
questions.a: We design the system around them. Outdoor beams can be mounted at specific heights, or pet-friendly PIRs used.

questions.q: Should I light up my garden?
questions.a: Yes, motion-sensor lighting is a great deterrent. Criminals hate being visible.

questions.q: Can I give a code to my domestic worker?
questions.a: Yes, we program a separate user code. You can track when they arrive/leave and delete the code if they resign.

questions.q: Is complex/estate security enough?
questions.a: Not always. You are responsible for your internal unit. We recommend a private alarm to alert you to breaches *before* estate security arrives.

questions.q: How do we prevent staff theft?
questions.a: Covert cameras, inventory access control, and strict user-logging on alarms help identify internal shrinkage.

questions.q: Can I monitor multiple branches?
questions.a: Yes, we can consolidate all your CCTV and Alarm feeds into a single Control Room dashboard or Headquarters view.

questions.q: Do you do fire evacuation systems?
questions.a: We integrate access control with fire panels to automatically unlock turnstiles and doors in an emergency.

questions.q: What is 'Time and Attendance'?
questions.a: Using biometric readers to log exactly when staff arrive and leave for payroll purposes.

questions.q: How secure are commercial alarm codes?
questions.a: Codes are risky (shared). We recommend tags or biometrics so you know exactly *who* disarmed the system.

questions.q: Can we grant temporary access?
questions.a: Yes, visitor management systems allow issuing temporary QR codes or PINs for contractors.

questions.q: Do you do roller shutter door sensors?
questions.a: Yes, heavy-duty floor contacts are designed specifically for warehouse roller doors.

questions.q: Can I listen to audio in the shop?
questions.a: Yes, audio monitoring is possible but must comply with privacy laws (staff must be informed).

questions.q: What about server room security?
questions.a: We install dual-authentication access (card + pin) and environmental monitoring (temperature sensors) for server rooms.

questions.q: Do you offer leasing?
questions.a: For large commercial installs, rental finance options are available through our finance partners.

questions.q: Can cameras survive dust and heat?
questions.a: Yes, we use industrial-rated (IP67/IK10) cameras designed for harsh factory environments.

questions.q: How do we secure a large perimeter?
questions.a: Thermal cameras and fiber-optic fence sensors are best for covering long distances without false alarms.

questions.q: What is 'Explosion Proof' CCTV?
questions.a: Cameras housed in stainless steel, pressurized casings for use in volatile environments like oil refineries.

questions.q: Can you track forklifts?
questions.a: Yes, we can install asset tags or driver-access control on forklifts to prevent unauthorized use.

questions.q: Do you install turnstiles?
questions.a: Yes, full-height industrial turnstiles are the standard for controlling factory shift access.

questions.q: Can we detect loitering?
questions.a: Yes, AI analytics can alert security if a person or vehicle remains in a 'no-stopping' zone for too long.

questions.q: What is 'Line Crossing' protection?
questions.a: A virtual tripwire on the camera view. If a human crosses a safety line (e.g., near dangerous machinery), an alarm sounds.

questions.q: How do night shifts access?
questions.a: Access control profiles can be set to allow specific shift workers access only during their rostered hours.

questions.q: Do you do weighbridge integration?
questions.a: Yes, linking cameras to weighbridge transactional data creates a visual log of every truck weighed.

questions.q: Is cabling safe in a factory?
questions.a: We use steel conduit or high-level trays to protect cables from machinery and forklifts.

questions.q: How do we power cameras in remote fields?
questions.a: Solar power. We build self-contained solar poles with batteries and wireless links for remote camera positions.

questions.q: Can you prevent livestock theft?
questions.a: Thermal cameras are excellent for this. They detect body heat of poachers (or animals) in total darkness over long distances.

questions.q: Does Wi-Fi reach the barn?
questions.a: Standard home Wi-Fi won't. We install Point-to-Point (P2P) wireless bridges to 'beam' internet kilometers across the farm.

questions.q: What alarm works for farms?
questions.a: Wireless outdoor sensors (like Ajax MotionCam Outdoor) are great. They send a photo to your phone when triggered, verifying the threat.

questions.q: Can we monitor the main gate?
questions.a: Yes, a GSM intercom allows visitors to call your cell phone from the gate, even if the gate is 2km away.

questions.q: Do wireless beams work through bush?
questions.a: No, they need Line of Sight. We may need to trim lanes or use repeater stations on hills.

questions.q: Is the equipment weather-proof?
questions.a: Yes, farm equipment must be rugged. We use UV-stabilized mounts and IP-rated enclosures.

questions.q: Can I monitor tank levels?
questions.a: Yes, easy integration with smart sensors can alert you if water levels drop or pumps fail.

questions.q: Do you do electric fencing for animals?
questions.a: We focus on security fencing (high voltage), but this effectively keeps predators out and livestock in.

questions.q: What acts as a siren on a huge farm?
questions.a: We utilize 'Long Range' radio transmitters to trigger sirens at the main house or workers' cottages simultaneously.

questions.q: What is LPR?
questions.a: License Plate Recognition. Cameras read plates at the gate and check them against a database of 'wanted' or 'resident' vehicles.

questions.q: How do visitors enter?
questions.a: We assist with systems like 'ClickOn' or 'GloVisitor' where residents send a PIN code to their guest via WhatsApp.

questions.q: Can you track guards?
questions.a: Yes, guard patrol baton systems ensure guards are actually walking their perimeter route.

questions.q: Who maintains the electric fence?
questions.a: The Body Corporate usually contracts us for monthly maintenance to ensure the estate perimeter is compliant.

questions.q: Do you monitor the control room?
questions.a: We build control rooms (screens, desks, software) for your on-site guarding force to operate effectively.

questions.q: Can speed be monitored?
questions.a: Yes, commercial radar speed signs or LPR speed calculations can flag speeding residents.

questions.q: Do residents need remotes?
questions.a: Remotes are common, but facial recognition or LPR scanning is becoming the prefered 'touchless' entry for residents.

questions.q: What about fiber networks?
questions.a: Many estates use a collection fiber network for security. We are experienced in fiber splicing and media conversion.

questions.q: Is biometric data private?
questions.a: Yes, strict POPI Act compliance is required. We help configure systems to store data securely.

questions.q: How do we handle contractors?
questions.a: Contractor stations with fingerprint enrollment and ID scanning ensure only vetted labor enters the estate.

questions.q: How do we secure the perimeter?
questions.a: A high, monitored electric fence combined with sturdy palisade is the standard. It must be checked daily.

questions.q: Can we control access to classrooms?
questions.a: Yes, wireless door handles (like Salto or Apexis) allow teachers access via card/tag, keeping rooms locked to students.

questions.q: What about lockdown procedures?
questions.a: We can install a 'Lockdown' button in the office that triggers a distinct siren tone and mag-locks specific doors.

questions.q: Do you monitor playgrounds?
questions.a: Yes, wide-angle fisheye cameras are great for covering large play areas to resolve bullying or injury disputes.

questions.q: Is student data safe?
questions.a: Yes, CCTV footage is stored securely with password protection, accessible only to authorized staff (Principal/Security).

questions.q: Can we prevent equipment theft?
questions.a: Computer labs are high-risk. We install 'Smoke Cloak' (pepper/fog) cannons and heavy-duty shutters.

questions.q: How do parents pick up kids?
questions.a: Traffic flow is key. Automated booms and verified pickup tags help manage the afternoon rush securely.

questions.q: Do you screen visitors?
questions.a: Video intercoms at the pedestrian gate allow the receptionist to visually vet visitors before buzzing them in.

questions.q: Are the systems rugged?
questions.a: Yes, we use vandal-resistant dome cameras and metal recess-mounted readers to withstand school environments.

questions.q: Can we monitor during holidays?
questions.a: Yes, the system is designed to act as a full alarm with off-site monitoring during school holidays.
